Hi Adriene, I really appreciate all that you share with us and I love that you read our comments. Every comment I have ever written has been liked and read by you which I find amazing and quite heart warming. You may remember reading about a little ferret named Chauncey, he joined me again today and was just lulled to sleep by your voice. I wanted to share his story with you and the community because it fits into this theme of "Home." Chauncey is a rescue, he was first found abandoned in the Garden Center of a Home Depot when he was just a kit. He was adopted out by a family and for three years was a companion to another ferret. Sadly, when that ferret died, the owners decided they no longer wanted him. He lost both his best friend and his home. He returned to the same rescue shelter as before, but now he was 4. He was considered an older/elderly ferret, which many people don't adopt. He was placed in a separate area from the rest of the ferrets at the rescue because he was excluded from the group. He spent about 6 months after that in solitude, until I adopted him. The fact that this energetic and loving animal was abandoned twice breaks my heart, but I know that he now has a forever home and I spoil him as much as I can so that maybe someday he can feel secure. This journey "Home" is as much of a journey for me as it is for Chauncey. It's suiting that my first yoga journey with him is called "Home" as I have found my new home at college and he has found his new home with me

The first 11 days have contributed to a better sleep, newfound strength and appreciation for my body. The challenge is helping me to get out of my head (I’m HSP) and I feel more grounded every day! I look forward to the new videos, knowing that so many others are committed to the same journey, and I’ve even joined a weekly yoga class to get a little more confident in the poses.

I have so much to say after that delicious practice. First--Wendell Berry's poem has become a mantra for me very often through the last year or so: "What we need is here." It weaves itself into my endeavors to create a hyper-local life full of art and good food and community and care. I am in the midst of two inter-related and completely disparate projects. One is imbuing my 2-acre cultivated land with perma-culture practices, and the other is producing a performance of Missa Gaia: Earth Mass created by the people in the Paul Winter Consort and now performed in a lot of different versions all over the world. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ksWvElS_-nE&list=PLw9KcFk9OmsDGrxBRiej-xrYItlXktaGu is where you can hear one of these community versions. These projects come out of a time of healing I was encouraged into by my wise body--crying our for more nurturing. Somehow that time I gave myself last year has resulted in the energy to engage these two projects which feel so right. But that's not even all: I've had the privilege of playing for several church services lately and this lyric from a hymn I learned as a child keeps coming up. "On the stormy sea, Jesus speaks to me, and the billows cease to roll." Marry all that with some recent study of Aramaic through books by Neil Douglas-Klotz: What I hear is the essential unity of what Yoga, and Christianity, and probably every other wisdom tradition teaches about finding the king-dom, or queen-dom within as a well of strength from which we can draw as we walk about in our world shining our light. Thank you so much, Adrienne for being our guide. Love and Light to you all.
